titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. IV. Saturday
Sun rose 4:25—from Charles’s House; rose behind the house on the hill.

I begin the month by writing in my Diary the record of yesterday: then in the Diary index ten days in November 1834—then by hearing my Grand daughters Mary-Louisa and Georgiana-Frances Adams read 5 chapters from 57 to 62 of Isaiah; all before breakfast— After breakfast I spent 3 hours in my Garden, seminary, Nursery and Orchard—observing my seedlings from eleven years old to those breaking the ground— Several of my wild cherries are just opening their blossoms— The fruit ripens 15 September— The leading shoot of one of my shag-bark walnuts, which opened from the bud since the first of May has grown two feet. I measured the largest white maple, from the seeds which I brought four years ago from Philadelphia and sowed 1 June 1835. it is 7 1/2 inches in circumference and about 12 feet high— I have only two remaining of the red flowering maple, from seed brought the same year 1835 from Washington; and only one of them that I can expect to live— It is in the centre of the Nursery—not a foot high; but with a thrifty shoot and large leaves of this Season— I had the languishing English Oak at the Northwest corner of the Nursery, and an Apricot tree in the centre of the garden thoroughly washed with Soapsuds to cleanse them from gathering moss— Ash leaves are putting forth from the seed leaves, in the new bed by the kitchen garden gate— A single Oak shoot appeared yesterday in Mary-Louisa’s Nursery-bed.— Three or four of my surviving black walnuts look as if they may yet live— The Althaea’s are but just putting out their leaves— The lilacs are gone having been in blossom a fortnight. Kirk hoed up one of my seedling cherries which I had transplanted from under the tree in the Orchard— I replanted it as a hopeless experiment— The stock from my apple-bud of 1832 in the Nursery has blossomed profusely and has fruit already formed. After dinner, I took up my father’s Diary from 1766 to 1773. and made an extract from it— In the evening I wrote a page of my translation of Horace’s Ode, on the praises of a Country life— Charles and his wife had spent the Evening here— The day was showery and so cold that I made a fire in my chamber— This day is a sample of my occupations for the month— I read also some pages of Mr Nathaniel Ingersoll Bowditch’s Memoir of the life of his father—a model of a self made man— My father’s diary is full of self chastisement for waste of time in visiting, conversation, and desultory reading—the last of which is my own bane.
2. IV:45. Sunday.

Communion day— Heard Mr Lunt this morning from 1. Corinthians 2.2. “for I determined not to know any thing among you, save Jesus Christ; and him crucified.” The Discourse was an ingenious argument for the truth
truth of the Christian Religion, drawn from the fact of the crucifixion of Jesus Christ— He pointed out the extraordinary contrast in the character and conduct of the Apostles before and at the time of the crucifixion, and fifty days after on the day of Pentecost— It was one of Mr Lunt’s best Sermons— The Communion was administered jointly by him and Mr Whitney— After dinner Mr Joseph Angier preached, from Isaiah 3.10. “Say ye to the righteous that it shall be well with him: for they shall eat the fruit of their doings. 11. Wo unto the wicked! It shall be ill with him; for the reward of his hands shall be given him”— He read also the 18th. chapter of Ezekiel, which so emphatically declares that every man shall be saved by his own righteousness and punished for his own sin— No vicarious atonement— There was an argument against the universalists, and another against the calvinists— I read the 7th Sermon of the 12th Volume of Saurin—upon the new misfortunes of the church: that is of the protestant church in France. There have been no persecutions of the Protestants more unmerciful than those suffered by the Protestants in France, for a full century after the revocation of the Edict of Nantes— Mr and Mrs George Dawes were here this Evening, and Mr Richard Cranch Greenleaf, and Miss Mary Whitney, whom he is at some time to marry— Charles and his wife were also here— I made out a list of all the Petitions from the 12th. Congressional District of Massachusetts; which I received for presentations to the House of Representatives of the United States at the late Session of Congress . . . and at the close of the Evening I copied verses. The 2d. Epode of Horace.
3. IV. Monday

Already this day, I broke in upon the order of my occupations, as I had prescribed it to myself, and lost the performance of some of the most essential of them— In order to complete my Letter to the inhabitants of the 12th. Congressional District, with the list of the Petitions from the towns in alphabetical order, for publication in the Quincy Patriot I began with it before breakfast, and it absorbed the whole day. I had barely time besides for the diary of yesterday, and all the rest was neglected— I spent indeed half the day about my grounds. Sawed off in the Nursery, two large peach-trees and one Apricot ten years old, but which have never born fruit, except one of them one year, in small quantities, and which are now so nearly dead that there was no prospect of their ever bearing hereafter— They cumbered the ground— All my peach-trees look sickly and ragged— I sawed off also the stock of an apple transplanted seedling at the Southwest corner of the Orchard—and there is a cherry seedling which I discovered close by it— A single Strawberry plant which I set out last Summer, in Fanny’s Nursery bed has blossomed, and is throwing out runners on all sides. Several of my black walnuts shew signs of life. The Rohan Potatoes are coming
coming up. The floor of the farmhouse kitchen was taken up, and one beam with three cross beam that passed over the top of the Well were found entirely rotten, and must be renewed— My wife, with Mrs John, Mrs Charles Mary Estelle Cutts and Fanny, to take tea with Mrs Frothingham, and to consult a doctress of Indian herbs—came home just before the Evening Bell— While they were gone Isaac H. Adams with John Foster, and Lieutenant Donaldson of the army were here; and Charles spent the Evening with us— I received a Letter from Mr Henry Colman; and a very strange one, from N. P. Trist U.S. Consul at the Havanna.
4. IV.10. Tuesday
Sun rose 4:23.— Saw it rise from Charles’s House.

I endeavoured to employ the day in regular order; but with little success— I. H. Adams was here— I visited my garden Nursery and seminary, turning my first attention to five American white Oaks, all that I have been able to raise, and four of which until this year have scarcely grown at-all— They are now thrifty and promising. I called at the book binders, with the pamphet copies of the acts of Congress of the 24th. and 25th. Congress— But the leaves were shaved so close that Mr Gill said he could not bind them in a volume corresponding with the rest— I desired him to keep them, and wrote to Aaron Vail, chief clerk in the Department of State, sending back three close cut pamphlets and requesting others entire in exchange— I took to the Office of the Quincy Patriot, my Letter to the Inhabitants, and Petitioners of the 12th. Congressional District, which he promised to publish next Saturday— He lent me the National Intelligencer of 28 May, which contains my second Letter to the Petitioners entire— After dinner, intending to write upon the biography of my father I missed his manuscript Journals, and the Memoir of his own life which he left unfinished, and wasted two long hours in searching for them, without success— Then going over to Charles’s, I found that he had them; but the day was gone and I had written nothing.— I had the rubbish of one of the library chambers in the farm house swept away— Charles and his wife spent the evening here— I filled a flower pot with fresh earth and sowed in it some of the elm seeds that I had picked up last week in Boston.
5. IV. Wednesday.

A thin border of clear sky along the eastern horizon deeply crimsoned by the Sun before he rose with the whole remaining hemisphere beclouded, gave warning of the day that was to follow The clouds closed over the serene so that the rising of the Sun could not be seen, and immediately afterwards it began to rain— Moderate showers with a brisk but not violent Northeastern gale, continued the whole day and evening and confined me to the House, where I wasted nearly the whole of it, in a very little writing, various reading, and pasting my name and arms in about 50 volumes in my library The
The trunk, two chests, and box of wine sent round by water from Washington came out this morning from Boston— I acknowledged the receipt of Mr Trists Letter—despatched the Letter and packet of pamphlet laws to Mr Vail, and began, but did not finish an answer to three Letters from Mr Henry Colman— My reading besides a part of the Memoir of Dr Bowditch’s life, and much newspaper trash was in the Massachusetts State papers; my father’s Letters to W. Tudor, Bradford and Hutchinson’s Histories, and the biography of my father in Sanderson’s lives of the signers of the Declaration of Independence said to have been written by Edward Ingersoll.— My search through these books was for the year 1768. the period at which I am resuming the memoir so long intermitted—but for want of the papers which Charles was to bring me, I could write nothing.
6. IV: Thursday.

Rainy morning, and chilly, still requiring a fire in my chamber. cloudy day, clearing off equivocally with the setting Sun. Charles and his wife and children dined with us; and Isaac H. Adams. I visited all my seedling plants, but found no new vegetation. The growth of the young trees is so luxuriant, that almost all the shagbark walnuts are top heavy, and bend, as if they would break down. My Diary and Index absorbed all the morning, and I only closed my Letter to Henry Colman. John A. Green the publisher of the Quincy Patriot was here, with a proof slip of part of my first Letter to the Petitioners which I revised— The Boston Courier of this morning contains about half the second Letter, with promise of the remainder to-morrow— After dinner I attempted to resume the biography of my father at the period of his removal from Braintree to Boston in April 1768.— I found in his manuscript, notice of his attendance on the superior Court at Worcester and Springfield that year, and that on his return to Boston, there was an army landed there; and that a Convention had been held.— For a full explanation of this I resorted to the 3d. Volume of Hutchinson where the facts are detailed, and to the Massachusetts State Papers, where are all the documents of the snarling controversy between Sir Francis Bernard and the General Court in 1768 are collected, but the reading of only a small part of them took me from my writing till the Sun was gone, and the twilight closed all my books— As the last labour of the day I copied six Stanza’s of a translation which some years since I made in Ottava rima of Ovid’s Epistle from Phyllis to Demophoon; which the best of all my compositions in verse, but never shewed to any person except my wife— She then made a copy of it for me, and it is from her copy that I am now making the copy for my Collection of Nugae Albae—White Lies—or Album Trifles— Fruits of the idle hours that I have wasted in rhyming.
7. III:50. Friday.

I saw them both from the eastern pillar of the portico of my Sons house— The length of the day, from the first rising to the last sinking beam of the Sun was by my observation fifteen hours and seven minutes; and by the American Almanac fifteen hours and eleven minutes— By the computations of the American Almanac, the morning solstice commences this day— That is the rising of the Sun at Boston, is marked from this day to the 18th. at 4:22—and on the 19th. at 4:23 and thence continues later every morning till the 30th. of December when it is marked at 7:30. and so continues till the 9th. of January— After which it recedes again to 7:29.— But the setting Sun marked yesterday and this day at 7:33. continues to set later till the 23d. marked at 7:40. and so continues till the 3d. of July—receding on the 4th. to 7:39. and continuing till the 4th. of December marked and thence to the 16th. at 4:28—so that by the American Almanac the length of the day from the 18th to the 23d. of June is 15 hours and 17 minutes— On the 4th. of December the setting sun is marked at 4:28 and so continues to the 16th.—and on the 17th. sets at 4:29. rising at 7:24. and continuing to rise later until the 30th. at 7:30— By this mode of computation the morning solstice is from this day to the 18th. and the Evening solstice from the 23d. to the 3d. of July.— While the Morning Winter Solstice is from 30. December to 9. January, and the Evening Solstice from the 4th. to the 16th. of December.— This the effect of the equation of time. But by the American Almanac the length of the day on the 15th of December is 9 hours 5 minutes on the 16th. and 17th. 9 hours and 4 minutes—on the 17th. again 9 hours and 5 minutes, and on the 18th. and to the 26th. again 9 hours and 4 minutes. There must be in this some error—perhaps of the press.— From the difference of true and apparent time the shortest night in Summer is 8 hours and 43 minutes: while the shortest day in Winter is 9 hours and 4. minutes— Still a mystery to me. In my Nursery visitations I found the leading shoot of the finest of my shagbark seedlings broken off—a sad disappointment. Kirke and Thomas mowed the grass in the seminary and front yard— Peonies open full— Visit from Edmund Quincy—convalescent, but an invalid— Elizabeth C. Adams dined with us— Mr Babcock, who was the teacher at one of the public schools, when I visited them last fall, brought me the proof slip of the remainder of my first Letter to the Petitioners, to be published in the Quincy Patriot to-morrow— The Letter to the Petitioners and inhabitants of the District, goes over to the next week— Charles went to Boston and returned home to dine. I brought from his house the volume of the Prior Documents, to consult for the year 1768.
8. IV. Saturday
Sun rose 4:22. not entirely clear—
Boston— Medford— Dinner with Mr P. C. Brooks— back to Quincy.

I went with Charles to Boston, and thence to Medford, and dined with Mr P. C. Brooks, and the trustees of the agricultural Society— Mr Brooks and his Sons Peter C. and Gorham, my Son, Nathan Appleton, Henry Codman, Henry Colman,Derby, Governor Edward
Edward EverettFinney. Benjamin Gorham, John C Gray, Benjamin Guild—William Prescott, Josiah Quincy junr. John Welles, and Thomas L. Winthrop were the company— Walk round the grounds of Mr Brooks’s garden before dinner— We returned home through Boston; and were housed at Quincy before nine in the Evening— We had stopped at Boston from 10 till 1/2 past one. I called at Mr James H. Foster’s, and saw Mrs Foster and her daughter Louisa— The family are in great affliction—Mrs Foster having recently had an apoplectic shock—Mary having been these two years in a decline—and William insane at a hospital— I visited the exhibition at the Athenaeum; where the collection is unusually large, with pictures purporting to be of great Italian, Flemish and Spanish Painters; but most, if not all of them copies. A Madonna with the infant Jesus, and John the Baptist of Raphael, a large picture of a master ship builder and his wife by Rembrandt, sundry pieces of Guido Guercino, and Van Dyke, entered on the catalogue as originals, are all copies— Others entered as copies; particularly the mistress and the first wife of Rubens are better— I met at the exhibition room Mr Isaac P. Davis, Mrs Stuart, the daughter of Mr Benjamin Buzzey, and Mr Charles Brooks and his Sister— After two hours at the Athenaeum I went to the chamber of the Historical Society, the key of which had been procured for me by Mr Isaac P. Davis, and I found him there— My object was to find the papers of the controversy between my father and Genl. William Brattle about the tenure of judicial office in 1773— I found Volumes of the Boston Evening Post by Thomas and John Fleet—and of the Boston Gazette by Edes and Gill, of the year 1773. both incomplete both weekly papers, published on Mondays. In Fleet’s Post of 4. Jany 1773 there is a Letter signed W. Brattle dated Cambridge 26. Decr. 1772. referring to some previous publication relating to a Town Meeting at Cambridge on the 14th. of December— And in Edes and Gill’s Gazette of 25. Jany. is a second Letter signed W. Brattle Jany 18. 1773. Cambridge—and in the same papers of 1st. 8. and 22d. Feby 1773 and Letters signed John Adams.— The Gazette of 15. Feby is missing.— Brattle’s Letter of 18 Jany. is in answer to a previous Letter of John Adams which I did not find— I had not time to read these papers— I called at Weeks Jordan and Cos. Book-store, to enquire if they had received from New-York a packet of my historical discourse— I had received this morning a Letter from Mr George Folsom Librarian of the New-York historical Society, mentioning that he had forwarded a packet containing 100 copies to Weeks Jordan and Co.— They had not received it, but the shop-man promised when it should be received to send it to Mr. Gillett driver of the Quincy Stage— At 1/2 past 1. I met Charles at Hawley-Place, and we proceeded to Medford— My wife, with Mrs John Adams, Miss Cutts and Mary-Louisa went also this morning to Boston, and returned home to dine— I received this morning Letters from Lewis and Pierce at Brooklyn LI—and from W. S. Smith at Washington— And a cover from J. L. Edwards Commissioner of Pensions enclosing a certificate of a five years pension of 600 dollars a year for Maria Varick of New-York.
9. IV:30. Sunday.

Heard Mr Pierpont of Boston, this morning from Genesis 1.3. “And God said, let there be light:”—a very ingenious and eloquent discourse; full of beautiful description and poetical imagery— With frequent indirect allusions to the fashionable darkness, and suppression of the light at the present time. Mr Pierpont cited in the course of his Sermon the first line of the third Book of Paradise Lost— “Hail! holy light! Offspring of Heaven first born”— He dined with us, and I asked him if he could tell the exact meaning of Milton in the whole of that passage? I said I understood it as expressing a doubt whether light itself is not eternal and uncreated; and hesitating whether he may avow this doubt. We examined the passage in Todd’s Milton, and found a note upon the passage by Newton, who understands it in the same way— But the 3d. verse of the 1st. chapter of Genesis seems very explicitly to affirm the creation of light by God, and of course the pre-existence of God— Mr Pierpont said that the word created in the first verse of the English Bible, does not in the original hebrew import absolute creation—but mere making. So says and argues Voltaire.— Mr Pierpont’s afternoon text was from Matthew 4:4. “But he answered and said, it is written, Man shall not live by bread alone, but by every word that proceedeth out of the mouth of God.” I read the 8th. Sermon of the 12th. Volume of Saurin, upon moral martyrdom; but scarcely had gotten through it, when Mr William Lee came to visit us; and stayed till after Sunset, and was followed by E. Price Greenleaf and then by Isaac H and Elizabeth C. Adams— The day was thus consumed; but I closed it by finishing the copy of my version of the heroid; from Phyllis to Demophoon; and copying my lines upon the Polestar and the Pointers. Charles was unwell, with a severe head-ache.
10. IV:15. Monday
Sun rose 4:22. By my Chronometer 4:30:50. from my window.

Mr French, a member of the Senate of the Commonwealth from the County of Norfolk, and an inhabitant of Canton, with Mr Everett, also a citizen of that town came this morning, as a Committee from the inhabitants of the town, without distinction of party, to invite me to deliver to them an address on the 4th of July approaching, which they have determined to commemorate.— I assured them of my great regret that it would not be in my power to comply with this invitation; having already declined two others for the same occasion—one at Bath in the State of Maine, and the other at Springfield in the County of Hampden—and having been also under the necessity for the last year or two, to decline all engagements for public speaking in advance, owing to the infirmity and uncertainty of my voice— They asked me then to send them a Sentiment, for a toast at the dinner, which I promised to do— Isaac H. Adams was here before, and E. Price Greenleaf after dinner—but I was napping when Mr Greenleaf came, and did not see him— Visited my seedlings, without making one useful observation—sowed sundry elm seeds, without probability that any one of them will come up. Wrote a short Letter to Lewis and Pierce of Brooklyn, Long Island, and shamefully wasted the rest of the day in idleness— I gave Mr French and Mr Everett each a printed copy of my two Letters to the Petitioners, whose petitions were sent to me for presentation to the
the House of Representatives of the United States, at the late Session of Congress.—having this morning received 30 copies of the second from Gales and Seaton; separately printed; as published in the National Intelligencer of 28. May— I received also 50 copies of the Jubilee of the Constitution—the Discourse prepared by invitation of the New-York historical Society and in part delivered before them on the 30th. of April last— Spent the Evening with the Ladies at Charles’s—Dr and Mrs Woodward were there.
11. III.30. Tuesday
Sun rose by my Chronometer at 4:27. from Charles’s house
Sun set, from the same porch at 7:37

Mr Lunt called, this morning; and observing that this was the year completing two centuries since the gathering of the Church at Mount Wollaston, said that he supposed it would be expected that some notice should be taken of it, and enquired if I had any books or information that I could give him—of historical interest; and to which it would be useful to advert— I lent him the volume containing Morton’s New English Canaan—Woods Wonder working Providence, and Johnson’sand also the copy of the first Volume of the Town Records. He said he had George Whitney’s History of Quincy, and Mr Hancock’s two Sermons, delivered on the first centurial anniversary of the gathering of the Church— I find on recurring to Winthrop’s Journal—Savage’s Edition that the day of the ordination of the first ministers Tompson and Flint was the 17th. of September 1639. with which the 29th. of next September will correspond—and that will be on Sunday I mentioned to Mr Lunt my belief that the first settlers of the town of Braintree came from a town of the same name in the County of Essex in England— My father thought they came from Devonshire. I sent by Charles to friends in Boston 9 copies of my New-York Discourse; but it seems as if it were impossible for me to accomplish any thing upon my father’s biography— This afternoon I looked up the papers relating to my Administration upon the Estate of Thomas Boylston de bonis non with the will annexed—for which I am under bond to the judge of Probate for the County of Suffolk in the penal sum of eighty thousand dollars— I found it necessary that I should petition the judge for liberty to accept the compromise of the claim upon Petty Vaughan, which has been approved by the judge of Probate for the County of Norfolk; for the Executors of Ward N. Boylston, and for the Execution of which Mr Vaughan has sent a Release ready drawn to be executed as well by me in the capacity of Administrator to Thomas Boylston, as by the Executors of Ward N. Boylston.— I began the draught of a Petition to the judge of Probate, but the afternoon was gone and I had made little progress in it— By observance of the rising and setting Sun from the same spot I found the length of the day 15 hours 10. minutes— Mrs Edward Miller with her Sister Mrs Spooner and her daughter were here this Evening, with Elizabeth C. Adams; and I spent an hour with my neighbour Mr William Appleton.
12. IV:15. Wednesday

list.head: Length of the day at my house 15 hours and 15 seconds.

div.p: Deacon Spear was with me, and left papers with me for the conveyance of one of my pews in the meeting house N. 74 to Seth Spear— I gave the Deacon the Congressional Document 297. containing the correspondence between the Secretary of the Treasury and the defaulting collectors and receivers of public monies, and a copy of my Discourse to the New-York historical Society, which I have called the Jubilee of the Constitution— After dinner Mr Henry Colman came with Mr Daniel Greenleaf who immediately withdrew, and left Mr Colman with me— Mr Colman has an appointment under the State Government as Commissioner of Agriculture for the Commonwealth, and he made some enquiries concerning my farming, which I told him was all by proxy— He left with me a sheet of printed enquiries relating to farming, which he asked me to give to my farmer J. J. Carr with a request that he would answer them upon the paper itself— He said he had been to the Mount Wollaston farm, and had given a similar sheet to Alpheus Spear, who had promised to answer the enquiries— But Mr Colman had another object which was to offer to write a Memoir of the life of my mother; whom he said he had almost adored: a proposal which I promised to take into consideration— Mr Colman is a highly respectable worthy and intelligent man; but the task of writing a memoir of the life of my mother ought to be performed by myself or by my Son— I answered a Letter from B. F. Presbury. C. R. Atwood, and W. Crocker, a Committee of young men of Taunton who propose to celebrate the next Independence day, and invite me to deliver the Oration before them. and a Letter from Mr John Marston enclosing theirs— I decline— I finished the draught of a representation, and Petition to the judge of Probate for the County of Suffolk, for his consent and approbation, for me as Administrator de bonis non, with the Will annexed of Thomas Boylston, the Indenture of release to Petty Vaughan— I am still dissatisfied with the employment of the day; too much of which was idled away in visiting my nursery, seminary and garden plantations, all of which I shewed to Mr Colman— I obtained from him no useful information respecting the raising of seedling trees; but he told me that there was a common prejudice, which he believed unfounded that the Ash tree is unhealthy— I had never heard of this before— I am taking some pains to save from death several cherry and black walnut trees in the Seminary—for which purpose Kirk dug round them and disencumbered their roots from weeds—particular attention to one budded cherry; and one black walnut which I had thought dead; but has within a few days put out a vigorous side shoot— Charles, his wife and three elder children dined with us, as usual every Wednesday. He and his wife spend with us every fair Evening.
13. IV. Thursday
Sun rose, by my Chronometer from Charles’s house at 4:26:25

My wife and Charles’s with Miss Cutts and Mary-Louisa went into Boston to see the exhibition of Pictures at the Athenaeum, and returned home to dinner— The Sun rose perfectly clear, but cloudly thickly before Noon, and after two or three showers of rain settled into a cold Northeastern gale without rain— Miss Cutts has a small Album with engraved devices at the top of some
some of the pages— There are some pretty lines of Edward Everett on a Cottage—and two lines equally ingenious and delicate from Mr Madison signed J. M.

lg.l: “Errors like straws upon the surface flow—
He who would search for pearls must look below.[”]

div.p: and below, are verses of Mrs Madison— There is a flat complimentary prosaic of Mr Clay— Miss Martineau says that Watts is laid under contribution for all the album poetry in this Country— I have seen very little in any Album so good as the worst verses of Watts.— I have kept copies of all my contributions to Album’s, and I sicken at the sight of them— Miss Cutts’s Album has been laying on my table these ten days, and I have been at my wits end for something to write in it— But she is now to leave us in a few days to visit some of her relations in Maine—and something I must write— There is at the top of one of the pages of the book an engraving of Roses in bloom, with a tambarine lying over them, and a lyre leaning upon the tambarine— The page below was blank,—and here was matter for musing meditation. I wrote a Sonnet, and having finished it, laughed aloud at myself to think what I should say, if she should ask me the meaning of it— “Fluttering spread thy purple pinions” is good sense and connected thought in comparison with it— A Sonnet of nonsense is better for an Album than pillage from Watts— Miss Cutts desires autographs also of my father and mother—and on looking over my mother’s papers I found the draught of a Letter from her to me written in 1783. and on the back of a Letter franked by my father, with his signature— I gave this to Miss Cutts— But all this absorbed the morning and I was barely able to write a short Letter to George Folsom, the Librarian of the New-York Historical Society— Afternoon I draughted a Deed of pew N. 74. in the Stone Meeting House, to Seth Spear, and began the Petition to the judge of Probate for the County of Suffolk, for authority to execute the Indenture of release to Petty Vaughan—
14. IV. Friday.

My long visits to my garden, Nursery, Seminary and Orchard are daily made, and constitute almost the only exercise that I take. They make me feel no small humiliation, at the numberless observations that I make and immediately forget—and at my own barrenness of invention, and utter ignorance of the art of training and medicating my trees— I spent three hours of this day in going over all my garden grounds; in witnessing the slow growth of the seedlings that survive; and the multitudes that perish— Kirk sawed off a large stump of an Apple tree in the Orchard, and cut away a whole bush of suckers around it, leaving one stem for an attempt to reproduce the tree.

Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— I sent by him a Letter to Mr Curtis, and the draught of a Petition to Willard Phillips the judge of probate for the County of Suffolk, which I propose to present next Monday as Administrator of Thomas Boylston.— I sent also ten copies of the Discourse to sundry friends in Boston. Mr B. F. Presbury, one of the Committee of the whigs of Taunton who propose to celebrate the anniversary of Independence, and sent me an invitation to deliver an Oration before them, came with a Letter from Mr Marston, and to repeat and urge the invitation.— I had despatched answers yesterday both to Mr Marston, and to the Committee, but they had not been received this morning. I repeated to Mr Presbury my regret at being unable to decline the invitation— Mr James Faxon came this afternoon with a Braintree tax of 1. dollars 36. cents for repairs on the highways & which I paid— After dinner I walked over the hill and plucked up two wild strawberry plants, which I set out in my seminary, to make again the experiment of transplanting the Strawberry for cultivation, with which I have twice failed. The plants before took root but bore no fruit. I have now taken a plant in bearing— Isaac Hull Adams and his Sister Elizabeth, Mr Beale and his two daughters spent the Evening here; and Mr Green the publisher of the Quincy Patriot brought me the proof slip of my Letter to the Petitioners from the 12th Congressional District of Massachusetts; to be published in the paper of to-morrow. which I revised, and returned to him. He promises me 100 copies of this Letter for distribution—
15. III:55 Saturday

The Sun rose by my Chronometer at 4:25:45 at the corner of Charles’s house— On perceiving his first beam I came immediately over to my own window, and at 4:30 found the disk of the Sun about 4 digits above the horizon; so that when the first beam appears here the whole disk is up from Charles’s house— A difference of 3 minutes, and 15 Seconds— The Sunset from Charles’s house was not quite clear, a cloud bordering the horizon into which the lower part of the Sun’s disk sunk before reaching the surface of the Earth—at 7:40— This gives 15 hours 15 minutes as the length of the day. By the American Almanac the Sun rose this day at 4:22. and set at 7:38 agreeing as exactly as possible with my observation, making an allowance of the Sun’s disk for the elevation of Charles’s house— I went the rounds of my garden Nursery Orchard and seminary; discovering only that the experiment of making a second Oak tree from the Black-jack Oak, by taking off the stem, and a long root, has failed, the severed stem, after putting forth puny leaves being now dead. The same experiment with the elm appears as yet to have succeeded.— The spindle chesnut Oak, which I topped in the summer house cellar has put out buds, and one of the seminary transplanted black walnuts which I thought dead has put forth a promising shoot— All the peach-trees are afflicted with crumpled leaves; yet many of them are bearing. I manured and watered the seedling beds to which I yesterday transplanted the Strawberry plants from over the hill.— The morning thus melted away— I finished reading the introductory Section of W. H. Prescott’s history
History of Ferdinand and Isabella, being the summary preliminary history of Castile— The Style is very good, and the evidence of research in Spanish documents exemplary; but it wants interest; and the perpetual commentary of Notes at the bottom of every page exceedingly tiresome— This practice is almost exclusively confined to modern English Historians and is in direct violation of all rules of unity in composition— Every note is a digression, and diverts the attention of the reader, from the subject— A very large proportion of these notes should have been woven into the text— Notes and Commentaries, except the mere citation of authorities, should be thrown into separate dissertations and published at the end of each volume—and there should not be many of them. I answered a Letter from Alfred L Kennedy who in the name of sundry Literary Societies at Philadelphia, has invited me to deliver an Oration before them on the 4th of next Month—the fifth invitation of the same kind for this year which I have declined— I wrote also to W. S. Smith, to Nathaniel Frye, and to Aaron Vail, which consumed the day. Evening at Daniel Greenleafs.
16 III:50. Sunday

Heard Mr Lunt this morning from Romans 7 22. “For I delight in the Law of God after the inward man: but I see another Law in my members, warring against the law of my mind, and bringing me into captivity to the law of sin which is in my members”— and Mr P. Whitney in the afternoon from 1. Corinthians 15.53 [“]For this corruptible must put on incorruption, and this mortal must put on immortality.” Mr Whitney is conscious of his own approach to the borders of the future world. His last Sermon on the 19th of last month was from this same 15th. chapter of 1. Corinthians and upon a future life— Mr Lunt made this morning a most impressive quotation from Paley: a remark upon John 5.28.29. [“]for the hour is coming, in the which all that are in the graves shall hear his voice—and shall come forth; they that have done good, unto the resurrection of life; and they that have done evil unto the resurrection of damnation.”— That if Jesus Christ had in his whole life done nothing more than speak those words he would have been a greater benefactor to the human race than all the philosophers that ever lived.— Perhaps this is hyperbolical— I believe the doctrine of future rewards and punishments indispensable to any system of good morals, but it was distinctly taught in the Greek and Roman Mythology— It was believed by the Jews before the time of Jesus, excepting by the Sadducees— It was no doubt the most essential and vital part of the Religion of Jesus and perhaps the only part which required his mission upon earth— The Law of benevolence, and the law of future retribution are the two pillars of Christianity. Without the former the latter is unnecessary— Without the latter, the former is useless. I read the 9th. Sermon of the 12th. Volume of Saurin, upon the disgust with the world and
and the contempt of life—not one of his best. The pictures of the miseries of human life are exaggerated— He remarks upon the contrast between the representations of life in the book of Ecclesiastes, and those in the proverbs of Solomon. I have often thought of them, and still more of the mutual opposition between the Ecclesiastes and the Song of Solomon— Saurin puts the question without answering it satisfactorily which of the two representations is to be considered as divinely inspired— There seems to be more of philosophical reflection in the Ecclesiastes and more of precept in the Proverbs— The wife of my farmer John J. Carr was this day delivered of a Son; after several years of marriage without a child.
17. III:50. Monday
Boston— Probate Court— Home to dine.

Beclouded morn and Evening— But I made an experiment of manuring the ground round the apple-seedling tree in the yard fronting my window, and near the gate and old Horse Chesnut. I went with Thomas Dumphy to Boston in Charles’s four wheeled Chaise— Met at his Office Mr Nathaniel Curtis, who went with me to the Probate Court Office—of which Willard Phillips is the judge, andPeabody the Register— I presented to the judge my Petition as Administrator de bonis non of Thomas Boylston, for his approbation and consent for me to execute the Release to Petty Vaughan a copy of which I presented with the petition— I presented also an account of Administration, charging myself with 9605 dollars 72 cents received of Petty Vaughan being the amount of the dividend of 3 and 6 pence on the pound of William Vaughan’s assetts; and claiming credit for the same sum paid over to the Executors of Ward Nicholas Boylston— I produced as a voucher the receipt of Mr Curtis and Mrs. Boylston; but the judge required also their assent to the account— Mr Curtis went with me to his Son’s house, in Pemberton Square. the new one—where Mrs Boylston was and where they both signed their assent to my account, which I was sworn to by the judge and it was admitted.— There is an Act of the Legislature of April 1838 authorising Executors and Administrators to compound for bad debts; which the judge shewed me, and said he thought it covered the whole case, and so thought I. He promised to have the decree made out by tomorrow; and it is then to be delivered to Mr Curtis for transmission to me— And then we are to execute the deed of release— Having found in the extracts from the Diary of Chief Justice Sewall, the time of my Ancestor Daniel Quincy’s Death, and that he made a Will I enquired for the record of 1690. and there found the Will, of which I requested Mr Peabody to have a copy made out for me, which he promised— I met Isaac P. Davis in the Street, who gave me a Letter to him from my old Classmate Dr Harris, with an offer of a nephew of his to copy papers for me, at a rate from 3 to 6 cents for 100 words— Mr Davis said Mr George Bancroft wished to come with him and visit me at Quincy this afternoon— I had stop’d this morning at Mr Bancroft’s, and at Mr John Welles’s, and left at each of them a copy of my Jubilee Discourse— Mr Alden Bradford called at Charles’s Office, and paid me for him 15 dollars for the rent of the pew in Brattle square Church— I met again at Foster’s livery stable, old Mr Francis
Francis Amory, who told me he had about a month since had a bad accident, of being thrown out of his carriage, from which he was but just now recovering— I returned home to dine, and after dinner received visits from judge Davis, his brother Isaac P. and Mr George Bancroft— They visited my Garden and Nursery; took tea, here and spent with me two hours very agreeably— Isaac P. Davis brought me another proposal for copying the papers of my father’s controversy with General Brattle, from a young man named Snelling who offers to do it for half a dollar a day which Mr Davis advises me to accept.— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here, as they usually do when the weather will permit— This was the anniversary of the Bunker’s hill, and there was a bustle of military parade in Boston—and some Symptoms of riot, upon a prosecution of a man for violation of the 15 gallon Law; but it pass’d off quietly.
18. IV. Tuesday

Beclouded sky—in the morning, and heavy showers at Night— Yet I endeavoured to aid the vegetation of a budded cherry tree, and a black walnut in my seminary— Of the ten transplanted cherry seedlings in the orchard two only give signs of life, and I have five plum seedlings between life and death. David Loud was here to enquire for the Land warrant and power of attorney which he says he sent to me, he thinks in the Winter of 1836–7. and which I have not been able to find— He says there is a man by the name of Bowditch who offers him 320 dollars for the warrant of 160. Acres— I made two long searches among my papers last Summer without finding those of Mr Loud, and I now promised to write to the Commissioner of the general Land-Office, for a copy of the warrant and to ascertain how another warrant may be obtained, instead of that which has been mislaid— I did accordingly write to Mr Whitcomb— The multitude of papers which accumulate upon my hands, particularly during the Sessions of Congress; together with a failing memory and the lack of the assistance of a Secretary, which during all the former years of my official life I had becomes exceedingly perplexing— I now very frequently mislay important papers of my own, and am for years together unable to find them— This is the first instance in which it has happened to me, with the papers of other persons.— My Diary has been extremely useful to me, for recurrence to papers after a lapse of years; and so I found it the other day, in looking up the papers concerning my Administration de bonis non of Thomas Boylston— But in the latter weeks of a Session of Congress, I have found it impossible to keep my Diary up with the current of time— During the three sessions of the last Congress I have received nearly two thousand Petitions to be presented to the House of Representatives—with hundreds of Letters full of solicitude concerning them— I have accordingly been obliged to keep a register of them which at the last Session, I published from time to time in the
National Intelligencer— Then my constant attendance in the House, the part which I take in many of the debates, and attendance upon committees, with a correspondence constantly pressing, and often upon bagatelles, form altogether such a pressure upon the brain that it often amounts to distraction— Household cares—domestic economy, and the prudent management of my private concerns add much to these labours, and social intercourse calls for its hours; and relaxation extorts others— Public and private affairs too often produce excitements under which I cannot write—and the languor of exhaustion, and the drowsiness that follows sleepless nights disable me from writing
19. III:30. Wednesday

Cloudy morning. Missed the observation of the rising of the Sun—but he set as observed from Charles’s porch precisely at 7:40, by my Chronometer, ten minutes later than from my house— There was a volunteer parade of a Quincy Military company with the Brass Band from Boston, who marched round the Streets, dined at French’s tavern, and fired a Cannon, at Sunrise Noon and Sunset— They marched by my house to the end of the garden, and then back and over the hill, intending it as I was informed for a salute— Charles with his wife, daughter and two sons dined with us as usual on Wednesday’s—and Isaac Hull and Elizabeth C. Adams with Miss Mary Harrod late from New-Orleans, and Miss Hannah Miller spent the Evening here— I wasted as usual idle hours in looking at my plants, and another portion in reading newspaper— I began a translation of Ovid’s Epistle from Paris to Helen, but on reading it over and the answer, I renounced the project altogether— The Epistle from Penelope to Ulysses, has nothing exceptionable in it, as to moral principle. That from Phyllis to Demophoon is as good as a moral Lecture; but these two are scandalous, and I will have nothing to do with them— Charles brought me out from Boston the copy of Daniel Quincy’s Will; which gives me a little more knowledge of that unfortunate ancestor of mine— The eldest son of the second Edmund Quincy—more than 30 years older than his brother the judge and agent of the Province who died at London— The marriage of Daniel Quincy was marked by one of the most signal instances of joy turned to mourning that real life ever witnessed.— It was solemnized at the House of Thomas Brattle, whose wife, the aunt of the bride, suddenly died, in the midst of the festivity, and her corpse was laid out in the bridal chamber— Daniel Quincy himself died of a consumption on Saturday the 10th. of August 1690.—under 40 years of age; leaving two infant children, one of whom John was my great-grandfather whose name I bear; and who made the name illustrious— This will was written and is witnessed by the Chief Justice Samuel Sewall and is dated 4. August 1690.— It is pleasing to me, by the bequest of a small bible with silver clasps to his daughter then 5 years of age; and of Pole’s annotations on the Bible, and his arms to his son John a child not a year old— And this is nearly all that I know of an ancestor whose
whose memory is yet very dear to me— I devoted more of this day than I could well spare to the extracts from Chief Justice Sewall’s Diary and began to make out minutes, to connect in a narrative the ascertained facts concerning my ancestry— This diverts my time from more necessary pursuits; mais c’est plus fort que moi.
20. IV. Thursday.

Sun rose, from the S.E. corner of Charles’ House precisely at 4:25. and was thus 8 hours 45 minutes, beneath the horizon. The day 15 hours 15 minutes long at the Summer Solstice— According to the American Almanac the setting of the Sun at Boston last Night was 7:39. and his rising this morning 4:23— Corresponding so exactly with my observation, that the allowance for a level horizon fully accounts for the difference— Mr Josiah Adams junr and Mr Jonathan French the Schoolmaster were here this morning— Mr French to borrow a map of the City of Washington which I have, but was unable to find— He borrowed a map of London; but afterwards came with two girls of his school, and exchanged it for one easier to copy.— He teaches his scholars to copy geographical maps— Mr Adams has not yet taken out the patent for his perpendicular bark cutter, for want of encouragement of purchasers though it has been very successful on trial— Deacon Spear was here after dinner, and I gave him the deed of my pew in the Stone Meeting house N: 74. to Seth Spear, which he and Louisa C. Smith witnessed— He told me that the Assessors had nearly doubled my town and County tax this year— We spent the Evening at Charles’s house— I received a Letter from Antoine M. Giusta, who has returned to Washington, from his visit to his friends and relations in Piedmont; and one from Mr. Nathaniel Curtis enclosing the decree of the judge of Probate for the County of Suffolk, authorising me as the administrator de bonis non with the will annexed to compound for the debt of Petty Vaughan.— Mr Curtis proposes that we should execute the deed of release to Petty Vaughan tomorrow or on Saturday— Among the title vouchers of the Mount Wollaston Estate, is an old plan upon parchment, damaged and which I had heretofore neglected— At the right hand of the outline, indifferently drawn is the following writing— “The land represented by this plott, belongeth to Mr Thomas Shepard (lying in the town of Brantrey) contaynethhundred acres (those parcels being deducted which belongeth to other men) and is bounded from A to B by Mr Edmond Quinsey, and the towne’s land: from B to C by marsh belonging to several persons; from C to D by marsh belongin to Gregorie Belcher, from D to E by the Town’s land, from E to F by Marsh belonging to Peter George from F to G by land commonly called Hoff’s neck, and from G to H by the Saltwater.[”]
The trees that are marked with lines, are generaly marked with S upon that side which is next to Mr Shepard’s land—at I isMr Veseyright at Q is a landing place.
Beneath this is a scale of 120 rods, and written over it. This plot is wrought by the scale of 50 link small division for two rods, and under the scale “finished the 1. December 1669. by F. ff[”]
Then at the right hand of the plan, and perpendicular to the other writing is the following—

That parcell marked G. B. and M. containeth 12. acres and belongeth to Gregory Belcher, and Richard Matson, and is divided from Mr Shepard at the print lineby upland, and upon the other side by a Creek and that parcell marked with B contayneth 8 acres upland and marsh, and belongeth to Samuel Belcher and bounded by a creeke dropt at L where is a line of stakes. The other parcell marked N. H. B. contayneth 8 acres, belongeth to William Nedham, John Holbrooke and Peter Brackett, and is divided from Mr Shepard’s upland as the print line runes, and upon the other side by a creeke dropt—a little spot at H which is staked out— It has taken me at least three hours to decypher and copy this old record, which shews very distinctly the bounds of the Mount Wollaston Estate in December 1669.
21. IV. Friday

Summer Solstice— Beclouded— Sultry morning Eastern chill afternoon— Misty fog evening. I made myself two hours of hard labour before breakfast by digging a trench across the border at the seminary gate to take out the stones under five seedling Apple trees of the second year, which were thriving, but the vegetation of which has stop’d— I wish to save the life at least of one of them— I took out about a bushel of stones; and filled the space they had occupied with mould from the brook over the hill, and from the garden—leaving the work unfinished for another day— Mrs John Adams and her two children with Miss Cutts and Charles, his wife and three elder children went to Boston to see the Giraffe, and Sully’s picture of Queen Victoria, which are exhibited now at Boston. They returned home to dine— Two young men, one named Butler now residing at Dorchester, and the other from New-Jersey named Mills, came on a visit of curiosity to see me and the house because we are both old— They enquired also, for the stone-quarries, to find which I gave them suitable directions.— Judge Davis left with me the other day a French Manuscript, being another explanation of the inscription upon the Dighton rock—or in the language of the original Explication de la Pierre de Taunston, par Moreau de Dammartin (Seine et Marne) Membre de l’Institut Historique— According to this learned Theban, the inscription is an Egyptian complete system of Astronomy—wrought at the winter solstice, and exhibiting all the great Northern Constellations.— There is no end to the absurdities of the human mind. The Phenicians, the Egyptians; the lost tribes of Israel, the Icelanders, the Welshmen with Prince Madoc; and the Basques have all been discoverers of America, to rob Christopher Columbus of his glory. Mankind will never be satisfied with History. They must have fables.— I spent the Evening at Charles’s house.
22. IV. Saturday
To Boston and home to Quincy to dine.
Foggy morning— Showery day.

Thomas Dumphy took me in Charles’s four wheeled chaise to Boston, where I met at Charles’s Office Mr Nathaniel Curtis and Mrs Alicia Boylston, and we executed three copies of the indenture of release to Petty Vaughan of the demand for the 10244 Sterling recovered from the French Government in behalf of Thomas Boylston’s Estate, which Petty Vaughan placed in the hands of William Vaughan and there melted down by his failure.— A dividend of three shillings and six pence on the pound has been paid upon William Vaughan’s Estate, and we reserve still the right to any future proportional dividend of the same— Mr Curtis called in Mr Benjamin R. Curtis who took the acknowledgments and with his brother GCurtis witnessed the execution of the three copies of the Indentures, which we had previously read together each of us holding a copy, and I reading alowed? the copy held by me— We also executed and acknowledged a Deed of 18 Acres of the land in Princeton to Hamilton Wilson for two thousand dollars. For the Execution of the release we are to receive a transfer of stock of the Bank of the United States, of 20000 dollars—but that cannot be made until the 1st. of next month, and in the mean time Mr Curtis keeps the indentures in his hands— I took to Boston, and left with Mrs Boylston the Book containing extracts and copies of Accounts and Letters between Thomas Boylston and Moses Gill the elder—to ascertain the amount upon this composition to be credited to the second Moses Gill— Mr Benjamin R. Curtis, though a young lawyer charged nothing for taking the acknowledgments— I called at Weeks and Jordan’s and found they had received from Samuel Colman the printer at New-York the remaining copies due to me, of the jubilee Discourse— Then at the State House, but I found the Council chamber locked— I then visited the Giraffe or Camelopard now exhibiting near the Court-house, with which was an Ibex—two animals called Bontibok’s of the goat species—a gazelle, resembling a lamb three months old; and two small monkeys— The Giraffe is a female—I should judge about fourteen feet high.— The keeper says 16. feet, and only 32 months old, not full grown— Gillett brought out the box and package of Jubilee Discourses.— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here. I wrote and sent a draft 300 dollars to M. A. Giusta.
23. IV. Sunday

Heard Dr Lamson of Dedham, this morning from Matthew 20.22. “Ye know not what ye ask.” and in the afternoon from Matthew 25.21 “His lord said unto him, Well done thou good and faithful servant: thou hast been faithful over a few things, I will make thee ruler over many things: enter thou into the joy of thy lord.” The morning Sermon was a discourse upon the vanity of human wishes—dwelling less on the special character of this most remarkable incident in the life of Christ, than upon the general unreasonableness of the desires of men—avarice ambition worldly pleasures, and the common place disappointments of
of the hopes and desires of men.— This occurrence is related with some slight variation in the gospels of Matthew and of Mark; but is not noticed in those of Luke or John— Matthew says the request was made for James and John by their mother— Mark says it was made by themselves— Is it not one of the mysteries of human nature that this selfish and unjust demand was made by the two disciples, precisely at the moment when he informed them that he was about to be abused reviled, and killed—but that he should rise again on the third day— Instead of being struck with horror and overwhelmed with sorrow at this annunciation, James and John, think of nothing but themselves, and ask to be advanced to honour and dignity and power in his kingdom, above all the other apostles: and this comes from two brothers one of whom was already by Jesus distinguished with partial affection— The rejection of the claim is pronounced with admirable dignity, and when the other Apostles manifest their resentment, at this spirit of encroachment upon their rights, he delivers the true principle of his Law, that the distinctions of his kingdom were to consist in pre-eminence of service and of suffering— Dr Lamson and Mr Charles Brooks dined with us— Mr Brooks has parted from his parish at Hingham; and is shortly to be married—and to go and pass the next winter in France to qualify himself for the appointment of professor of Natural History in the University of New-York— I read the tenth Sermon of the 12th. Volume of Saurin— Upon the little success of the ministry of Jesus Christ— His text is from Romans 10.21. a disobedient and gainsaying people— He says that the Jews were always so; and tells his auditory that they themselves are not a whit better, and if they had lived in the days of Christ would have crucified him as did the Jews— I saw the Sun set both from my own house, and from Charles’s—the latter at 7:40. Charles and his wife, and Mr E Price Greenleaf spent the Evening here— Miss Cutts at Mr Edward Miller’s.
24. IV:30. Monday.

Yesterday morning I found in Louisa Catherines seminary plat a seedling walnut tree just out of the ground, and this morning in John Quincy’s plat an Oak— These are the first since the solitary oak which appeared on the 31st. of May in Mary-Louisa’s plat, which put out a stem about 3 inches long and opened four leaves, which have developed themselves and turned brown— The stem has not since grown a hair’s breadth— I found one nectarine on the transplanted tree near the South-east corner of the house which I have given to John Quincy besides his platt— Found a ripe wild Strawberry in the Garden and 3 Kean Seedlings— Sowed the Wild Strawberry in the bottomless flower pot, and one Kean Seedling in the Summer house cellar— Had the alley fronting the seminary border weeded.— Mr Jacob Norton was here this morning with Mrs Lucy Dawes; and Archibald Campbell with Isaac Hull, and Elizabeth C. Adams, Mary and Georgiana Harrod— In the afternoon Miss French came with a subscription paper for the Sunday School Library.— Dr. and Mrs Frothingham with three children, Ward, Ann and Ellen came out from Boston to Charles’s, and stop’d a few minutes here on their way. Mr Frothingham attended a clerical convocation at Mr Lunt’s. Mrs Frothingham
Frothingham took tea at Charles’s— We were there in the Evening— I came away with my wife— Mrs John, Mrs Charles Adams and Miss Cutts went afterwards to Mrs T. B. Adams’s— Deacon Spear brought me a note of Seth Spear dated the 20th. payable in four Months with interest. No small portion of the day was consumed in packing up and despatching copies of Congressional documents—of Letters to the Petitioners and of the Jubilee Discourse— All my useful occupations are suspended. Reading nothings in Newspapers absorbs time enormously— And Letters asking for autographs, and inviting me to deliver orations addresses and Lyceum Lectures, seem to me as if they would never end— Among the Letters this day received was one from Henry Williams, asking for publication my opinion upon the constitutionality and expediency of the fifteen gallon law; an act of the Legislature passed in 1838. forbidding the sale of ardent Spirits in quantities less than 15 gallons— A measure of overheated zeal for the restraint of intemperance, and which is operating a revolution in the State against its administration, and in favour of the general administration of Martin Van Buren
25. IV:30 Tuesday.

Planted a ripe Kean seedling Strawberry surrounded by a dozen red cherry stones just ripe in a flower pot, which I placed on the Seminary plat—next to those of the six children— The Elm seeds which I sowed towards the close of the last month have all failed; but many seeds of the Ash, which I sowed with them, and which had wintered in my closet have come up— I made an attempt this day to resume useful occupation, but with little success— Enclosed Dr Robbins’s manuscript Report to President Quincy; and answered the second invitation of the Bristol County whig Committee and the Letter of Mr John Marston declining again to attend their proposed celebration of the Anniversary of Independence. I called at the Stone bank, and at the Office of the Quincy Patriot— Green is to publish the second Letter to the Petitioners entire next Saturday— I called also at Gill the Bookbinder shop, but being past noon it was shut— After dinner I had a short visit from Mr. Nathan Warren of Weston, with his wife and daughter— A dealer in cattle who came here upon business, and had a curiosity to see me— Charles went to Boston and returned home to dine— I saw the Sun set from his porch not quite clear at 7:40.— He and his wife, and Campbell and Isaac Hull Adams spent the Evening here— I receive every day large packages of Congressional Documents extra copies of which were ordered by the House of Representatives to be printed, but which could not be printed till after the close of the Session of Congress— I distribute them chiefly among my constituents, and despatch a basket full of them almost every day— Besides these, I have now my second and third Letters to the Petitioners, and the jubilee Discourse to distribute; and of them all together, I send between 30 and 40 packages to the Post-Office Every day— Drudgery, I fear to no good purpose.
26. III.30— Wednesday

Last day of the Summer Solstice— Saw the Sun rise from Charles’s porch; not quite clear at 4:24. Set in a cloud. Planted three Kean seedling Strawberries and a dozen red cherry stones in a flower pot; and the like in the centre of Louisa Catherine’s seminary plat— My wintered Ash seeds come up, wherever I have sown them—but none of the Elm-seeds— Charles and his wife, with their three elder children, Mrs John Adams and her two daughters—Isaac Hull Adams and Campbell made a party for the day, and went to Cohasset and Nantasket beach, where Dr and Mrs Frothingham went from Boston and met them— My wife was unwell and could not go—and I for lack of inclination, went not— They came home before Sunset. Hull and Elizabeth C Adams were here in the Evening.— I visited my plants— Directed Documents and Jubilees— Diarized, and recommenced indexing— Answered two invitation Cards from the Mayor of Boston, one to attend the city celebration of Independence day—the other to his “at Home”—that morning declining both. And began an Answer to the Letter from Henry Williams requesting my opinion upon the constitutionality and expediency of the fifteen gallon licence Law. As often happens to me, I was stopped in the midst of this Letter by an embarrassment what to say, and did not finish it— I met Mr Lunt yesterday as I was walking over the hill, and mentioned to him that the first gathering of the Church, and choice of Mr Tompson and Mr Flint as Ministers is twice mentioned in Winthrop’s Journal as having occurred on the 17th. of September 1639. and that the corresponding day according to the new Style, in the present year will be the 29th. of September which will be on a Sunday— The celebration of the first centennial anniversary was on the 16th. of September 1739. also a Sunday—and in a note to Mr Hancock’s Sermons then preached it is said the church was gathered on Monday Septr. 16. 1639— I should think Winthrop’s Journal the best authority.
27. III:45 Thursday.

I intended to go to Boston to attend the Meeting of the Historical Society; but found myself too unwell, with a flying rhumatism portentous of an Easterly storm— Charles and his wife were also both unwell, and my wife’s health is drooping— I planted three wild garden Strawberries in a flower pot with several ripe red cherry stones, and two Kean Seedlings in one of the plats— I answered the Letter from Henry Williams, asking for publication my opinion upon the constitutionality and expediency of the fifteen-gallon licence Law: and I received a Letter from Joshua Leavitt and Henry B. Stanton for the Committee of Arrangements of the American Anti-Slavery Society, earnestly inviting my attendance at a National Anti-Slavery Convention to be held at Albany on the 31st of July next— These appeals to me for my opinions, upon subjects convulsing the public mind with the conflict of interest and passions are at once flattering and perplexing— So flattering that they have an evident tendency to engender self-conceit, and a fatuitous over-estimate of my own importance— I ought to know, and never for a moment forget that my opinion is not of the weight of a straw to influence that of the public upon any great question of politics or of morals— Common prudence should warn me not to mingle unnecessarily with controversies, without a distinct and unequivocal call of duty— And this is the more incumbent
incumbent upon me, because my opinions without being useful to others draw down a load of obloquy upon myself and even upon my family— Yet when my opinions are formally asked, common civility requires an answer—the refusal to give an opinion would manifest either churlishness, or a selfish timidity affecting discretion— This license-Law, is an ill-advised measure, intended to promote the virtue of temperance, but infringing the personal freedom and habits of the people— A profligate use of the passions of the people is made to overthrow the present State administration, and turn it to the benefit of Van Buren— And it is among the strange anomalies of party management that the political agency of the Anti-Slavery party produces the same effect— This National Anti-Slavery Convention will be followed by the same result.— My answer to Mr Williams will not satisfy him nor any one else— And while the Abolition champions are importuning me to attend their convention all their newspapers with one voice have opened in a grand chorus against my Letters to the Petitioners— I spent an hour of this Evening at Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s— He is afflicted with a singular disease in the throat.— Charles was here.
28. IV: Friday

Rain almost they whole day—first with a Southeast and afterward with a Northeast wind but without storm, and scarcely sufficient to saturate the earth. Charles went to Boston and returned— I should have done much on such a day as this; but did nothing, except answering an invitation from T. B. Wakeman, corresponding Secretary of the American Institute at New-York to deliver an anniversary Address before them next November—which I decline— In the attempt to redeem the arrears of my Diary-index, I bring back the memory of many things, which appear to me in different lights from what they did at the time when they occurred— One of the most trying periods of my life was that of the close of the 23d. Congress, when after a most furious succession of debates, buffeted from all quarters of the house, I brought them to an unanimous recorded vote; and thereby combined to ruin me the whole power of the Senate, and especially all the rival aspirants to the Presidency then in that body.— The vile expedient of insulting the House of Representatives by a message to remind— Of defeating the fortification bill, by a hypocritical by-blow at the 3 million appropriation and of charging the House with the loss of the bill itself—indicated to me what was to come; and I saw the danger in all its magnitude— The storm did burst upon me, at the next Session of Congress, by an elaborate and deeply studied Speech of Webster delivered on the 14th. of January 1836. in the Senate, and published four days after in the National Intelligencer— The whole speec was a masked battery opened upon me; which I completely silenced, and turned back upon its inventor but by what a whirlwind of invective against me it was followed from almost all the eloquence of both Houses— I never replied—though with a full reply I was prepared.
But my policy towards France was fully sustained by the Event and I was saved from political destruction by my resistance against the gag of May 1836— These were casualties or providential incidents— I spent this Evening, with Mrs John and Mary E. E. Cutts at Charles’s.
29— IV:15 Saturday
Sun rose 4:25. Set 7:40. day 15 hours 15 minutes.

I took to the book binder Caleb Gill junrs. shop a collection of printed pamphlets of my writing to be bound up in a volume, to give to my Granddaughter Mary Louisa— I have the materials for a second Volume, and the collection will yet be very imperfect— Of several of my earliest published pamphlets I have only one copy left— Of some—particularly of the Report on the case of John Smith of Ohio, I have no copy at-all— But of pamphlets in number sufficient to make two thick Octavo Volumes, I have copies enough to make up a set for each of my six grand children—and as the three girls being the eldest have asked me for copies of my Oration at Newbury-Port and for the Jubilee of the Constitution, I have put together with them copies of all the supernumeraries, to be bound up to give them as tokens of memory, when I shall be forgotten by the rest of the world— I am making a more complete collection, of the same pamphlets, with others of which I have only one copy, to leave to my Son.— I called also at the Office of the Quincy Patriot with a minute of the Petitions omitted from the published in the list in the paper of the 15th The second Letter to the Petitioners generally is not yet published; but Green promised that it shall be next Saturday— I received a Letter from Mr Charles Brooks, mentioning that at the annual Session of the American Lyceum at New-York in May last, a Committee was appointed to call a National Convention to meet at Philadelphia on the 22d. of next Novr. to discuss the subject of Education: and inviting me to attend, and to preside at this Meeting— Also a Letter from James Whitcomb Commissioner of the general Land-Office enclosing a certified copy of the Land Warrant issued to David Loud father of Warren Loud a soldier in the last War with Great Britain— Call at J. Briesler’s shop, and ordered four earthen flour pots, for seed sowing— A Shagbark Walnut up in Seminary plat 7. Gathered red cherries, one week before ripe— Afternoon ride with Charles to Milton and Dorchester— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here— G. W. Beale here and invited us to a meeting of the Proprietors of Neponset Bridge at Squantum next Tuesday.
30 IV.15. Sunday
Sun rose 4:25.— Set 7:40. Day 15 hours 15 minutes.

Heard Mr Lunt this morning from Ecclesiastes 1:18.— “he that increaseth knowledge increaseth sorrow”—and in the afternoon from Psalm 139.7. “Whither shall I flee from thy presence?[”] He handled with delicacy and with dexterity the morning text, and noticed the contrast between the general tome of this book, and that of the proverbs where the acquisition of knowledge as promotive of the happiness of man— They are certainly different views of human life; and taken from different positions— The Song—the Proverbs and the Ecclesiastes are the vivid portraitures of the three Stages of the Life of Solomon—Youth—Maturity and Old age.
The afternoon discourse was upon the omnipresence of the Deity both good Sermons; but that of the morning the most impressive. I read the eleventh Sermon of the 12th. volume of Saurin, upon Libertines and unbelievers—admirable— He says that in all his experience of attendance upon the sick and the dying of these two characters he had never met with one who adhered to the character in the Article of death— Mrs Mifflin and Miss Elizabeth Crowninshield were here to visit Miss Cutts; and Coll. Bomford with Mr. Alger came out from Boston— Mr Alger has a Cannon foundry at South Boston, and Coll. Bomford has come from Washington to contract for casting great guns of heavier calibre than have ever before been used. The effect of the French Steam-battery upon the Castle of Saint John d’Ullea has set all our military minds in commotion.— Mr Alger by some casualty mentioned that he came from West Bridgewater, and said that he remembered something of the full bottomed wig of his uncle Shepard Fisk.— I asked him how Shepard Fisk came to be his uncle— He said he had married his Grandfather’s Sister, and lived and died at West-Bridgewater in the same house with his Grandfather— I told him that I had long been in search of information relating to Shepard Fisk, who was half-brother to my Great-Grandfather John Quincy, a son of the same mother Anna Shepard; who after the death in 1690 of her first husband Daniel Quinsey, married Moses Fisk the Minister of the first congregational Church in Braintree, and by him had this Son Shepard Fisk— On looking over Farmer’s Register I find it stated that Shepard Fisk was a physician, at Killingly Connt. and at Bridgewater, Massachusetts, and that he died 14 June 1779. at the age of 77 whence he must have been born in 1702 I asked Mr Alger if he had papers which could afford information concerning Mr Fisk’s life He said he had many books left by him and among the rest his family Bible in which there might be entries respecting his family— He promised to look them over, and if he should find in them any thing interesting he would communicate it to me— It is strange that Mr Alger should be under the impression of having seen Shepard Fisk in his wig, and that he remembered his funeral when he is himself is only 59. years old, and Mr Fisk has been dead 60 years— I wrote Letters to Edward Brooks to Charles Brooks, and to Mr Thomas French at Canton— Saw the Sun set from Charles’s porch; and spent the Evening with him. Mr and Mrs William Appleton, and Mr Augustus Whitney were there— Charles’s wife, with Mrs John and Mary E. E. Cutts spent the Evening at Mr Miller’s— This was the first unequivocal Summer day of the Season—

Day. I rise between 4 and 5. always before the Sun—sometimes between 3 and 4. on clear mornings I go to see the Sunrise from the corner of Charles’s house. Visit my seminary plants—and water the pots— Sometimes take a turn in the garden— Diarize—read the newspapers and Letters brought by the mail breakfast between 8 and 9. Garden Orchard—writing till 2— Waste afternoon and Evening
